From the Economist 
“Canadians vote today in a general election which polls suggest will result in a hung parliament and possibly a new party in power. The governing Liberals, led by Justin Trudeau, look likely to win roughly as many seats as the opposition Conservatives, under Andrew Scheer. If neither party gets a majority, then either would need support from smaller parties to govern. The centrist Liberals could look to the left-leaning New Democratic Party, whose leader, Jagmeet Singh, has ruled out supporting the right-leaning Conservatives. That duo share some common ground on climate change, immigration and the need for a single-payer drug programme. The Conservatives might turn to the separatist Bloc Québécois, which has sometimes backed them in the past. But the Bloc’s leader, Yves-François Blanchet, dislikes the Conservatives’ lack of zeal on climate change, and says his party will divvy out its support, issue by issue. In 2015 the Liberals won convincingly; expect a cliff-hanger today.“

Polling aggregation numbers suggest a 63% chance currently that the Trudeau government will win the most seats, with an ~38% chance at a majority government (and conversely a ~25 percent chance at a minority government). This is about equal to the odds given for the Conservative party to win a minority government, which are currently sitting around ~24.5%. [1]. While the blackface scandal had a seemingly measurable effect based on the changes in polling after public reporting, trend lines seem to indicate that this was more of a temporary effect, with polling numbers regressing back to the 20-25 point margins that have held consistent since the election was announced.  Demographics play an key role in the eventual outcome of the  election. LPC holds significant leads in both Quebec and Ontario, and as long as this trend continues they will be heavily favoured to win the most seats. As of 29 September, LPC led voting intentions by an average 16 points in the least populated ridings. In the most populated, Liberals lead by on average by 26 points [2]. It is unlikely with almost two weeks left to the election that this will change significantly. I am no expert on Canadian politics. However, I begin with several questions, premises, and a conclusion.
Q1: Will Justin Trudeau have a majority support of the seats in the House of Commons? If so, he will continue his term and the answer is no.
Q2: How many members of the House of Commons currently support him? 
Q3: How many members are required to have a majority of the House of Commons?
Q4: Does the House of Commons reflect the voting population?
Q5: Does the voting population vote based on economics primarily, as Americans do?
Premise1: Unemployment rate in Canada is touching historic lows.
Premise2: Unemployment rate is a proxy for Canadian economic outlook.
Premise2: Canadians vote based on economic outlook.
Premise3: Canadians have positive economic outlook.
Conclusion: Canadians will re-elect Justin Trudeau by a narrow margin.

One of the arguments for why Trudeau would lose has been that his climate policies will make unpopular. Data just came out that weakens this argument as it shows majority of Canadians in vast majority of ridings support climate policy and carbon pricing in particular [1] (admittedly not large majorities).  In the way of context, carbon prices have historically been extremely unpopular and helped the toppling of more than one government, including in Canada. This continues to be very uncertain to me (hence the close to 50% forecast)  A good read: https://www.tvo.org/article/one-pollsters-advice-for-doug-ford-and-andrew-scheer Some takeaways for me:
* typical polls (that ask “who would you vote for if the election was held tomorrow”) may be less predictive at this stage than “deserves to be elected” polls. The latter are not great for the Trudeau at 24% nationally.
* Scheer is running into trouble with his association with the Ontario’s Premier Ford and this is showing up in the polls. “While the federal Conservatives remain in a strong position across most of Canada, the Liberal surge in Ontario has taken what appeared to be a probable Andrew Scheer-led Conservative federal government and made the picture much more uncertain.”
* Trudeau’s accomplishments have been on issues (such as climate change) that may be less immediately important to voters: “The Liberals have left a lot of bread-and-butter issues on the table that Scheer can use to galvanize voters.” As a broader point, one has to consider the error margin of the polls that far out. Yes they are showing a Conservative win as more likely but how predictive is that? An analogy: In weather forecasting, one can use meteorology (weather simulations) vs. climatology (long-term base rates). The former is generally valuable up to two weeks out and beyond two weeks the latter is more predictive (for a reference I point you to Silver’s Signal and the Noise). I posit that some version of this is true for traditional polling vs. long-term base rates.  One long-term base rate source is the one I analyzed previously where I had looked at frequency of re-election in Canada which showed the average length of service of a PM is 6.5 years https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/878966. Another possibly better approach would be to tie the strength of the economy to odds of re-election.

My baseline is 62%. Recent polls that put the liberals at a 30% chance to win the most seats (whether or not they win a majority). I think this number is artificially low, because of the recent news surrounding the Liberal party (and Trudeau in particular). Though the news is certainly not positive, the other parties have yet to propose a coherent plan for how they will govern. At some point the other parties will have to take positions and that should turn the debate towards new topics. The liberals should get a bump when the coverage changes to substantive political issues rather than gossip. However, I added a 50% discount to account for the possibility that Trudeau might be replaced as the leader of the Liberal party, in which case the Liberals could still win, but the answer to this question would be "no". Why TK%? The baseline is 42%—i.e. by my calculation, 42% of Canadian Prime Ministers have been replaced by someone in their own party, rather than someone from another party. Given the recent news, there have been mentions of Trudeau resigning or being replaced. I still do not think that he is more likely than not (i.e. >50% chance) to be replaced, but recent events need to pull my prediction up from the baseline.  Therefore, if I predict a 38% chance of the liberals taking most seats, apply a 50% discount to give Trudeau a 19% chance of remaining party leader, The chance that he will cease to be prime minister is 81%

With the recent Wilson-Raybould scandal, polls indicate that the Federal average supports for the Liberals and Conservatives have changed slightly to 34 versus 37%, but they are still within the margins of error [1].  However, the CBC Monte Carlo simulations predict drastically different results from a month ago.  The forecast probability for a Conservative majority and minority government is 22.4% and 27.2%, respectively, yielding a total of 49.6% (compared to a mere 33% a month earlier) [2]. Interestingly the “leadership” polls for Trudeau did not change much [1].  He is still consistently ahead of the Conservative leader by 10 to 20 percentage points, and also ahead of the NDP leader (by more than 20 percentage points).  This popularity will help him in the crossover vote described in the next paragraph. Since the Liberals and NDP are both left of center parties, there will be crossover votes from the NDP to the Liberals since NDP has no chance of getting the plurality of the votes in this coming election.  This crossover happens frequently near the end of the campaigning. I estimate a 10% crossover votes. This number is estimated based on the NDP crossover to the Liberal in the 2015 election [3], and the Liberal crossover to NDP in the 2011 election [4]. I subtract 10% from the 50% to account for the end of campaigning crossover.  [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_43rd_Canadian_federal_election

Canada has a history of polling starting at the beginning of a Parliament session to the next election.  Some of these data can be found in Wikipedia [1] and [2].  The polls for the upcoming election can be found here [3].  Examining these data suggests that there were frequent drastic shifts in the support for the parties in the last couple of months before the election.  Therefore using the current poll results for forecasting the election results could be way off. To it as it may, currently the Federal average supports for the Liberals and Conservatives are within the margin of error (37 versus 35%, respectively).  CBC performed Monte Carlo simulations to predict the outcome of the election, using the current poll results.  (Thanks to @nigster for providing the link [4]).  The forecast probability for a Conservative majority and minority government is 16% and 17%. respectively, yielding a total of 33%.   Since the Liberals and NDP are both left of center parties, there will be crossover votes from the NDP to the Liberals since NDP has no chance of getting the plurality of the votes.  This happens frequently near the end of the campaigning.  I estimate a 10% crossover votes.  This number is estimated based on the NDP crossover to the Liberal in the 2015 election [1], and the Liberal crossover to NDP in the 2011 election [2].  I subtract 10% from the 33% to account for the end of campaigning crossover.
